repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Strategic Urban Roads
            Infrastructure Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings for the Indonesia
            Strategic Urban Roads Infrastructure Project are as follows:
            Project outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is modest; Bank performance
            is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is satisfactory.
            Among the lessons learned: 1) Good project management
            facilitates effective project implementation. 2) Flexible,
            supportive supervision by Bank staff is essential to ensure
            effective implementation and respond to changed
            circumstances. 3) Major road improvements need to be
            integrated into urban structure. 4) Controlling access to
            new roads requires more than by-laws. 5) Proper design
            procedures are essential. 6) Final engineering designs and
            full bidding documents must be completed and checked as
            compliant before tendering. 7) QLI-type schemes can be
            mainstreamed but local ownership is essential. 8) Capacity
            building can be successful even with changes in the
            organizational structure if the capacity building comprises
            modular training programs related to specific technical
            topics and guidelines on good practice in planning, design
            and procedures that can be applied by a group of technicians
            or professional staff in their daily operational tasks 9)
            There are several steps to decentralization of functions
            from central to local government, which take time to
            implement and then more time for various organizations and
            their staff to settle into their new roles. 10) For
            effective formulation and dissemination, urban transport
            policy needs a single strong agency to be responsible.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Strategic Urban Roads
            Infrastructure Project (SURIP)

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Strategic Urban
            Roads Infrastructure Project are to: 1) reduce traffic
            bottlenecks on the national roads in selected urban areas in
            the North Java corridor; 2) address the environmental and
            social issues associated with the increased usage of the
            national road network in these urban areas; 3) assist the
            government of Indonesia (GOI) in the process of
            decentralizing responsibility for the planning, design,
            construction, maintenance, management and regulation of
            urban transport from central to local government as set out
            in recent government regulations; 4) strengthen technical
            and institutional capabilities, particularly with respect to
            dealing with environmental and social issues, of GOI's
            central and local government agencies involved in urban road
            development and management; and 5) assist GOI in the
            formulation, articulation and implementation of urban
            transport policy. The project comprises the following five
            components: 1) road construction; 2) urban management and
            quality of life improvements; 3) institutional and human
            resource development; 4) GOI urban road program development;
            and 5) policy articulation and implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Strategic Urban Roads
            Infrastructure Project (SURIP) : summary environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This report is a summary of the
            environmental impact assessment of the Strategic Urban Roads
            Infrastructure Project (SURIP).  The purpose of the previous
            impact assessments of the five initial SURIP projects were
            to identify potential project impacts as well as measures to
            minimize, manage and monitor adverse impacts.  Based on
            these impact studies, this environmental assessment has been
            prepared to comply with project appraisal requirements of
            the World Bank and is organized into the following seven
            chapters: 1) project description; 2) environmental and
            social impact assessment framework; 3) existing
            environmental and social conditions; 4) significant
            environmental impacts; 5) analysis of alternatives; 6)
            environmental impact management and monitoring; and 7)
            social impact management and monitoring.
